qas.question: What have scholars argued about with regards to nastika and astika philosophies?
In what centuries the writings of scholars been used to debate the philosophies?
What are Buddhism and Jainism regarded as in relation to religion and philosophy?
What are other schools regarded as within Hindu philosophy?
How available are the sources of knowledge on Indian philosophy?
When were the astika and nastika philosophies written?
What are the two sibling traditions?

plausible_answers.text: history and concepts, same textual resources, similar ontological and soteriological focus, and cosmology

qas.question: What differentiates the various sibling traditions?
What do scholars agree on within the astika and nastika philosophies?
Which two named philosophies are considered to be the same?

context: Scholars have debated <b8_0>the <a0_0>relationship and differences<b8_0/><a0_0/> within āstika philosophies and with nāstika philosophies, starting with the writings of <b6_0>Indologists and Orientalists<b6_0/> of <b5_0>the <a1_0>18th and 19th<a1_0/> centuries<b5_0/>, which were themselves derived from <a4_0>limited<a4_0/> availability of Indian literature and medieval doxographies. The various sibling traditions included in Hindu philosophies are diverse, and they are united by shared <b7_0>history and concepts, same textual resources, similar ontological and soteriological focus, and cosmology<b7_0/>. While <b9_0>Buddhism and Jainism<b9_0/> are considered <a2_0>distinct<a2_0/> philosophies and religions, some heterodox traditions such as Cārvāka are often considered as <a3_0>distinct schools<a3_0/> within Hindu philosophy.
